channel.title: NYT > Home Page
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: City Room: New York Today: Summons Season
item.description: What you need to know for Tuesday: Summer’s smaller crimes, possible rain, and the first family moves to Gracie Mansion.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE CORREAL
item.media:description: Living on the edge.

item.title: DealBook: French Officials Twist U.S. Arms in Bank Inquiry
item.description: The French banking giant BNP Paribas has enlisted the support of its own government, which has raised concerns that a looming penalty for doing business with Sudan and Iran is unduly harsh.
item.dc:creator: By BEN PROTESS and JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France reviews troops in the courtyard of Les Invalides in Paris.

item.title: Obama, in Warsaw, Pledges Solidarity With Eastern Europe
item.description: As he began a four-day European trip, President Obama announced more steps to bolster security in central and eastern Europe with additional deployments and training.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Euro Zone Edges Closer to Dreaded Deflation
item.description: Consumer prices in the 18 nations of the euro zone rose at an annual rate of just 0.5 percent in May, further pressuring the European Central Bank to ease monetary policy.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: In California Chrome’s Barn, a Hopeful Network of Relative Strangers
item.description: The connections behind California Chrome’s run at the Triple Crown have one thing in common: They all fell hard for him in their own way.
item.category: Harris Farms Horse Division of Harris Rach Beef Co
item.dc:creator: By JOE DRAPE
item.media:credit: Matt Roth for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steve and Carolyn Coburn feeding California Chrome at Pimlico Racetrack in Baltimore.

item.title: Your Fellow Americans: How to Succeed in Washington Without Really Trying
item.description: Become a cause célèbre. There’s never been a smoother path from anonymity to Wolf Blitzer’s greenroom.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LEIBOVICH

item.title: Amid Fear and Pressure, Syrians Vote for President
item.description: The election is certain to confirm Bashar al-Assad’s hold on power amid a civil war that has killed an estimated 160,000 Syrians.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A man votes for President Bashar al-Assad, marking his ballot with blood. The vote in Syria is expected to hand Mr. Assad another seven-year term.

item.title: Bowe Bergdahl’s Vanishing Before Capture Angered His Unit
item.description: The release of the U.S. soldier has created political problems for both parties amid allegations that he had left his base without permission.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT, HELENE COOPER and CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Fearing Converts to Terrorism, France Intercepts Citizens Bound for Syria
item.description: Amid worries about a threat from radicalized Europeans who fight in Syria and then return, France is arresting would-be jihadis even before they leave the country.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Relatives in Tel Aviv mourn those killed at the Jewish Museum in Brussels. The suspect was said to have spent time in Syria.

item.title: Citing Pressure and Threats, Egypt’s Answer to Jon Stewart Calls It Quits
item.description: Bassem Youssef, a satirist who poked fun at the politically powerful, said he was ending his television show out of concern for his safety and that of his family.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: Bassem Youssef, a satirist who took on post-revolutionary Egypt, said Monday at a news conference in Cairo that he was ending his television show.

item.title: A Long Island Institution Is Cooling Its Ovens
item.description: By July, Entenmann’s will close its Long Island bakery and lay off 178 of the plant’s workers. Its pastries will still be sold in the New York area, but will be baked at other plants.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH BERGER
item.media:credit: Bryan Thomas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Entenmann’s, which opened on Long Island in 1905, will shutter its Bay Shore bakery and lay off 178 workers. The popular discount outlet will remain.

item.title: Anger Among Indians After Killings of 2 Girls
item.description: The rape and hanging of two girls have incited outrage in India and fury against the state government and the police.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: The grandmother of two Indian girls who were raped and hanged in India’s Uttar Pradesh state.

item.title: At Belmont Stakes, Tom Durkin Will Try a Final Time for a Triple Crown Call
item.description: The Belmont track announcer Tom Durkin has called seven Triple Crown attempts and may still see a victorious effort before he retires later this year.
item.dc:creator: By JOE DRAPE
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Durkin at Belmont Park.

item.title: Seattle Approves $15 Minimum Wage, Setting a New Standard for Big Cities
item.description: The City Council’s unanimous vote guarantees workers the highest big-city minimum wage in the nation, and more than double the federal level.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK JOHNSON
item.media:description: Mayor Ed Murray of Seattle, right, after the City Council approved a minimum wage that is more than double the federal minimum. The $15 rate is the highest among the nation’s big cities.

item.title: Recorded Noise Might Offer Clues to Missing Plane
item.description: A low-frequency noise might have indicated an ocean impact, and scientists are to provide details on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: De Blasio Family Begins Move to Gracie Mansion
item.description: Mayor Bill de Blasio and his family are engaging in a timeworn New York City ritual — moving from one borough to another.
item.dc:creator: By KATE TAYLOR
item.media:description: Gracie Mansion, at East End Avenue and 88th Street in Manhattan. Mayor Bill de Blasio and his family will make an unhurried move out of Brooklyn.

item.title: Strategy and Objectives for Gaining Soldier’s Release Shifted Over Time
item.description: For more than two years, the Obama administration maneuvered to make a deal to free Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl the start of a larger peace process for Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and ASHLEY PARKER
item.media:description: Stickers showing support for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl at Zaney’s coffee shop in Hailey, Idaho, where the soldier worked as a teenager.

item.title: Hospital Charges Surge for Common Ailments, Data Shows
item.description: Hospitals charged more for every single one of 98 common ailments in 2012, and the increase for all but seven exceeded the nation’s 2 percent inflation rate for that year, according to a Times analysis.
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.dc:creator: By JULIE CRESWELL, SHERI FINK and SARAH COHEN
item.media:credit: C.J. Gunther for The New York Times
item.media:description: An artificial hip procedure. In 2012, hospitals charged more for every single one of 98 common ailments that could be tracked.

item.title: Democrats in Coal Country Run From E.P.A.
item.description: President Obama’s proposal to cut emissions from coal-fired power plants could become a key election issue in some battleground states.
item.dc:creator: By TRIP GABRIEL
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coal-fired power plants, like this one in Ghent, Ky., are at the center of the debate on climate change.

item.title: Taking Page From Health Care Act, Obama Climate Plan Relies on States
item.description: A plan that offers the states a menu of policy options could also lead to a patchwork of rules that frustrate businesses and invite resistance.
item.dc:creator: By CORAL DAVENPORT and PETER BAKER
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coal-fired power plants, like this one in Ghent, Ky., are at the center of the debate on climate change.

item.title: Birds Leave Nest Involuntarily, and Oakland Fumes
item.description: The outcry began when the Postal Service decided to prune trees by its parking lot in Oakland and five baby herons fell from their nests, but some people say the situation has descended into absurdity.
item.dc:creator: By CAROL POGASH
item.media:description: Cat Callaway, left, told a tree-trimming crew to stop when she saw herons that had fallen. Lisa Owens Viani, right, took them to a rehabilitation center.

item.title: After Boy and Girl Are Stabbed, Anger Over a Lack of Cameras
item.description: Community leaders said the search for a man who fatally stabbed a 6-year-old boy and critically wounded a 7-year-old girl was being complicated by a lack of video surveillance.
item.dc:creator: By VIVIAN YEE and MARC SANTORA
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicholas Avitto outside the building where his 6-year-old son was killed in an elevator.

item.title: New U.S. Effort to Aid Unaccompanied Child Migrants
item.description: FEMA will take charge of coordinating relief efforts as a second shelter is opened in response to a recent influx of young illegal immigrants.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:description: A Honduran child sat with other Central Americans waiting to be processed at the Border Patrol station in Brownsville, Tex.

item.title: Ex-Brooklyn Prosecutor Charles J. Hynes Accused of Misuse of Funds
item.description: An inquiry has implicated Mr. Hynes, the former Brooklyn district attorney, in the improper use of money seized from drug dealers and other criminal defendants to pay a political consultant more than $200,000 for his work on Mr. Hynes’s unsuccessful re-election campaign last year.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHANIE CLIFFORD and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.media:description: Charles J. Hynes in 2013.

item.title: Hopes for Impact of Carbon Rules in U.S. Are Modest
item.description: Reductions in coal use will come from relying more on other power sources and making structures more efficient, but both are already happening.
item.dc:creator: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS and DIANE CARDWELL
item.media:description: Production of alternative energy, like that made at the Ivanpah Solar Electric Generating System in the Mojave Desert in California, is expected to increase under new carbon rules.
